channel.title: NYT > International Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Counterintelligence Agents Search State Department Pakistan Expert’s Home and Office
item.description: After the F.B.I. searches, the diplomat, Robin L. Raphel, was put on leave. Her spokesman said, “I’m confident this will be resolved.”
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Special Section: Relief Work in Ebola Zone Is Fraught With Risk
item.description: Those who go abroad to scenes of disaster or conflict already take considerable personal risks — and those who go where Ebola is prevalent can face misunderstanding at home as well.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN SCHWARTZ
item.media:description: Dr. Rick Sacra, who contracted Ebola in Liberia, left isolation at Nebraska Medical Center in September and was reunited with his wife, Debbie, and son Jared.

item.title: ‘Dark’ Network of Illegal Websites Targeted by U.S. and European Police
item.description: A series of raids and arrests by American agencies working with Europol shut down more than 50 black market sites selling illicit goods and information.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Jobs Data Show Steady Gains Even as Voters Signal Anxiety
item.description: While the report was upbeat, with a survey finding a big increase in the number of people who found a job last month, wage growth continued to drag.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA COHEN
item.media:credit: John Rucosky/The Tribune-Democrat, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A recent job fair in Somerset, Pa. Election Day exit polls found that two-thirds of those surveyed said they believed the economy was getting worse.

item.title: Ed Miliband, British Labour Party Leader, Denies Rumblings of Discontent
item.description: Publicly, at least, no lawmakers have called on him to quit, but several days of poor newspaper headlines reflect disappointment in his performance, opinion surveys show.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Matthews/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ed Miliband, the British Labour Party leader, buying a bacon sandwich this year. He has come under fire for his eating technique.

item.title: Explosions at Fatah Sites in Gaza Raise Tensions With Hamas
item.description: The militant group Hamas, now a partner with its longtime rival Fatah, denied responsibility, but many were skeptical.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: Regional Politicians Approve Restart of Nuclear Plant in South of Japan
item.description: The reactors at the Sendai plant would be the first brought back online under new safety standards introduced in the wake of the Fukushima disaster.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Spanish Court Upholds Tax Fraud Charges Against Princess Cristina
item.description: The court agreed to drop the more serious money laundering charges that were also filed against her.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Princess Cristina of Spain in February. She has been entangled in a graft case centered on whether her husband and his business associates embezzled millions of euros.

item.title: China and Japan Reach Accord on Disputed Islands: Let’s Agree to Disagree
item.description: Signaling a potential thaw in their long-frozen relations, the two nations said they would work to keep tensions in the East China Sea from escalating.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Indian Navy Ship Sinks, Killing at Least One Crew Member
item.description: The vessel, used to collect torpedoes from practice firings, developed a leak off the coast of the southern Indian port of Visakhapatnam.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: South Korea Sets Independent Inquiry Into Ferry Disaster
item.description: South Korean legislators passed a bill initiating the inquiry into the sinking of the ferry Sewol in April, which killed 304 people.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Jerusalem Unrest Underscores Need for Peace Talks: EU's Mogherini
item.description: The EU's new foreign affairs chief said on Friday that a surge of violence in Jerusalem made it all the more critical that Israel and the Palestinians return to negotiations quickly.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: To Impress APEC Leaders, China Cracks Down on Beijing Life
item.description: Determined to show a cleaner version of Beijing, the Chinese authorities have ordered dozens of temporary changes that are upending people’s lives.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: China and Japan Agree to Resume Dialogue
item.description: China said Friday it reached agreement with Japan to ramp up high-level contacts, the strongest indication yet of a possible meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at next week's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sports of The Times: Problems With Antidoping System Cast a Shadow on Kenyan Runners
item.description: The Kenyan marathon runner Rita Jeptoo failed an initial doping screening, raising questions about doping enforcement in that African nation.
item.dc:creator: By JULIET MACUR
item.media:description: Rita Jeptoo of Kenya, a three-time winner of the Boston Marathon, recently failed an initial test for the banned substance EPO.

item.title: Lens Blog: Family Time on Prison Buses
item.description: A little-known network of buses and vans takes people from New York City to visit relatives in prisons scattered in small towns across the state.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW BORYGA
item.media:description: Attica is a maximum-security prison in upstate New York. Like all maximum-security prisons, Attica has walls instead of fences, which are reminiscent of medieval castles.

item.title: In Britain, Guidelines for Spying on Lawyers and Clients
item.description: British spies have the authority to intercept privileged communications — and may have illegally exploited that access — according to confidential documents that were released Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Another Ex-Commando Says He Shot Bin Laden
item.description: Robert O’Neill, a former member of the Navy SEALs, has come forward claiming to have shot the Qaeda leader during the daring operation in Pakistan in 2011.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH, CHRISTOPHER DREW and SEAN D. NAYLOR
item.media:credit: Walter Hinick/The Montana Standard, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Robert O’Neill, a former member of SEAL Team 6, has said that he fired two shots that killed Osama bin Laden.

item.title: Midterms, for Clinton Team, Aren’t All Gloom
item.description: The Democratic debacle in Tuesday’s midterm elections has put fresh urgency on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s efforts to create a blueprint for a 2016 presidential candidacy.
item.dc:creator: By AMY CHOZICK

item.title: Secret FIFA Report Stirs Dispute Between Investigators
item.description: A report on the circumstances surrounding the winning World Cup bids by Russia and Qatar has not been released, and the men at the center of the investigation disagree about whether it should ever be made public.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Michael J. Garcia, left, at the end of a news conference in Zurich in 2012 with Hans-Joachim Eckert, a German judge who has chosen not to release Garcia’s report on the 2018 and 2022 World Cup bids.

item.title: In Ukraine Crisis, U.S. Businesses Face Tit-for-Tat Response to Sanctions
item.description: American brands doing business in Russia have become political targets since the European Union and United States enacted sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Max Avdeev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Once hugely popular in Russia, McDonald's recently reported its steepest quarterly decline since 2002.

item.title: Meager Returns for the Democrats’ Biggest Donor
item.description: Tom Steyer, the billionaire environmentalist who spent at least $57 million of his own money to influence Tuesday’s outcome, appears to have largely wasted his time and money.
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Tom Steyer at a school in October. The $57 million he spent on the elections backed few winners.

item.title: ‘Red Army’ Charts Rise and Fall of a Soviet Hockey Team
item.description: “Red Army” traces the rise and fall of the Soviet hockey team of the 1970s and ’80s, whose grace and skill were unmatched, even as the players chafed at restrictions.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLES McGRATH
item.media:description: The Soviet hockey team’s much-feared “K.L.M.” unit in 1988.

item.title: Takata Saw and Hid Risk in Airbags in 2004, Former Workers Say
item.description: When secret tests a decade ago showed its airbags could crack and explode, the company tried to erase the evidence, former employees said.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Inside a Takata showroom in Tokyo on Thursday.

item.title: Court Upholds Marriage Bans in Four States
item.description: Setting up a Supreme Court case, the decision overturned lower court rulings in Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee that were in favor of same-sex marriage.
item.category: United States Court of Appeal for the Sixth Circuit
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By ERIK ECKHOLM
